Why do flow loop rules have this priority?
+10 is not enough, it will intersect with QinQ rules. Need at least 11, but better 50 or 100 (so you can use -10 as priority step for default-port rules).
Do we really need both looped and loopSwitchId fields? I propose to treat loopSwitchId != null as a looped marker.

Use FlowSideAdapter instead of PathSegment is it much more clear - at least you don't need to know is the ingress switch included in the first path segment or not.
And avoid extraction of dependent objects segment.getPath() there was a huge amount of errors created by such coding approach.
according to current naming loop rules are called ingress and transit.

??? Why it is here? I mean why it is into metadata? Is the corresponding IngressFlowLoopSegmentRequestFactory not informative enough to define these requirements?
PS Don't see the usage of these fields.
I would like to use OfAdapter.INSTANCE.makeVlanReplaceActions() here as a reference approach to calculate vlan's stack update.

I would like to suggest other terminology... because we don't have the egress loop, I would not use the ingress term here. Let's name it endpoint loop i.e. in this case it will makeEndpointLoopRequest and EndpointLoopSegmentRequestFactory (can't say should we include flow anywhere in this name).
PS I don't have a better name for transit loop segment.

I prefer naming ingress/transit loop. From flow perspective loop rules either forward traffic input to output (just like single switch ingress rule) or forward traffic to next switch in a looped path (just like transit rule).

Now when we have 2 kind' of requests, we should rename existing makeIngressRequest, makeTransitRequest and makeEgressRequest into makeIngressSegmentRequest, makeTransitSegmentRequest and makeEgressSegmentRequest.
No. You must not allow this. Search for other solution.

nodes.bodyText: System may not have any looped flows
Can we move it to the DB level?

From performance standpoint, it's better to refactor this method into 2 traverses with subsequent concatenation:
String switchIdAsStr = SwitchIdConverter.INSTANCE.toGraphProperty(switchId);

List<Flow> result = new ArrayList<>();
        
framedGraph().traverse(g -> g.V()
                .hasLabel(FlowFrame.FRAME_LABEL)
                .has(FlowFrame.SRC_SWITCH_ID_PROPERTY, switchIdAsStr)
                .has(FlowFrame.LOOPED_PROPERTY, true))
                .frameExplicit(FlowFrame.class)
                .forEachRemaining(frame -> result.add(new Flow(frame))));

framedGraph().traverse(g -> g.V()
                .hasLabel(FlowFrame.FRAME_LABEL)
                .has(FlowFrame.DST_SWITCH_ID_PROPERTY, switchIdAsStr)
               .has(FlowFrame.LOOPED_PROPERTY, true))
                .frameExplicit(FlowFrame.class)
                .forEachRemaining(frame -> result.add(new Flow(frame)));

return result;

In this approach the indexes are used instead of full scan.
A switch statement inside another switch is very confusing. Pls, consider refactoring - e.g. move into a method.
The return value of OfAdapter.INSTANCE.makeVlanReplaceActions() is not used anywhere.

Perhaps we should/can use another coordinate system. For example side identifier (source/dest) and the number of switches from this side 0..N. Relative address is simpler from flow modification perspective, but harder if you need to hit into the specific switch.
This is just an idea to think about.
Add "0x" prefix to get rid of any ambiguity.
q-in-q will be covered in next patch
I have changed naming. Is it better from your perspective?
You loose looped flag in .toBuilder().build() cycle. Also you need getter for it.
other properties are named via underscores.

This checks already in FSM code
Move it into some method. And you can make this check flow side/endpoint, not for whole flow. Just extend EndpointDescriptor with the required data.
Moved to method. I don't think EndpointDescriptor is useful here.
We are making the same rule for single-switch and for multi-switch flows is it expected behavior?
Ingress loop rule is dependent only on input port and vlan stack so it's the same for single-switch and multi-switch flows.
Here you have a direct and indirect fill of rules. I would like to not mix these approaches, it makes it difficult to understand from reading in one glance.
